Project Number: 52174-001 
Transaction Technical Assistance (TRTA) 
June 2018 
 
 
 
People’s Republic of Bangladesh: Implementing the 
Emergency Assistance Project 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Public Communications 
Policy 2011.

I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT  1

I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  The proposed Emergency Assistance Project will support the Government of Bangladesh 
in addressing the urgent needs of the  displaced persons from Myanmar in Coxsbazar District, as 
identified by the United Nations (UN) in its Joint Response Plan (JRP) (displaced persons).1 The 
project is aligned with the following impact: social recovery of displaced persons in Teknaf and 
Ukhia camps accelerated.2 The project will have the following outcome: living conditions and 
resilience of displaced persons improved. The project will improve water supply and sanitation, 
disaster risk management, sustainable energy supply, and access roads. The project is estimated 
to cost $120 million ($100 million through an Asian Development Fund grant and $20 million from 
the Government of Bangladesh).3  
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
2.  The technical assistance (TA) will support government agencies,4 including the Refugee 
Relief and Repatriation Commission (RRRC)5 and implementing agencies,6 in (i) strengthening 
and sustaining institutional and technical capacities; (ii) planning, designing, and implementing 
the proposed subprojects; and (iii) establishing an effective monitoring and evaluation system.  
 
3.  The emergency assistance project will be implemented by multiple implementing agencies   
and the project is envisaged to substantially use the advance fund procedure. The risk due to 
weak capacity of accounting staff to adequately manage the internal controls and financial 
management is high. Financial management assessment of the implementing agencies has 
indicated that the consolidation of expenditures and their liquidation will be a challenge. Similarly, 
noncompliance with the financial management system can expose the project to fiduciary risks 
and audit objections.  
 
4.  The project follows the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) 
and the Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended from time to time). The 
implementing agencies need support in familiarizing with the new ADB procurement policies. 
                                                
1 UN, Strategic Executive Group. 2018. 2018 JRP for Rohingya Humanitarian Crisis, March–December 2018. Cox’s 
Bazar. Various terminology is used in media, official and unofficial documents to describe the affected people. 
Terminology used herein is intended solely to identify such people for the purposes of this paper, and not to assert 
any view regarding the manner or circumstances of such persons’ displacement. Such terminology may not reflect 
the terminology used or accepted by any government or any agency thereof. ADB expresses no view and takes no 
position herein regarding the legal rights or political assertions or the characterization of any such persons. The use 
of the term “displaced persons” in this paper is not intended to have the same meaning as the term “displaced 
persons” defined in ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). 
2  Defined by the project. 
3  The provision of a grant to Bangladesh from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Special Fund resources (Asian 
Development Fund [ADF]) for the project is subject to the Board’s approval of a separate proposal (submitted in 
parallel to this paper) waiving provisions of applicable ADB policies that would otherwise prohibit such grant support. 
Prior to submission of this proposal to the Board, ADF donors endorsed the allocation of $100 million in ADF 
resources to provide special grant support to Bangladesh for the project. 
4  Government agencies include the divisions of the line ministries who are responsible for executing the projects, such 
as Local Government Division under the Ministry of Local Government, Rural Development and Co-operatives; Road 
Transport and Highways Division under the Ministry of Road Transport and Bridges; and Power Division under the 
Ministry of Power, Energy and Mineral Resources; and the Deputy Commissioner of Coxsbazar.  
5  RRRC is a designated coordinating agency acting on behalf of the Ministry of Disaster Management and Relief for 
interagency coordination and support for displaced persons in Coxsbazar. 
6 Implementing agencies include (i) Local Government Engineering Department; (ii) Department of Public Health 
Engineering; (iii) Roads and Highways Department and (iv) Bangladesh Rural Electrification Board.

2 
Being an emergency project, procurement actions need to be fast-tracked using open competitive 
bidding with local advertisement, limited competitive bidding, request for quotation, or direct 
contracting, as appropriate. Fast-tracking procurement activities require additional procurement 
support to executing and implementing agencies. Lack of transparency, collusion among the 
contractors, and nontransparency in distribution of goods and equipment to beneficiaries are 
foreseen.  Substantial  monitoring,  audit,  reviews,  and  procurement  support  will  be  needed 
throughout project implementation.  
 
5.  Risk assessment during project due diligence has indicated that the likelihood of weak 
capacity  and the  lack of  dedicated key  staff will  hamper  subproject selection, fast-tracked 
implementation, and the timely completion of due diligence. Subproject selection, preparation and 
approval of development project proforma and technical assistance project proforma, and project 
implementation are challenging under capacity constraints and low subprojects’ readiness. The 
implementing agencies are not prepared to deal with the scale of the emergency project at short 
notice. The project will need strong support in subproject selection, project planning, design, 
packaging, and procurement (including contract management).  
 
6.  Because of the influx of new population into the communities, the risk of increased human 
trafficking, drug trafficking, and sexually transmitted infections (including HIV) is high. Awareness-
raising programs on the gender equity and social inclusion action plan will need to be conducted 
in all campsites throughout the project period. Some project areas may fall under the protected 
forest and critical natural habitat, which will need a high level of safeguard due diligence during 
subproject selection and implementation. 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
7.  Output 1: Institutional capacity strengthened. The TA will focus on enhancing the 
project implementation capacity of government and implementing agencies by providing capacity 
building and resource support in (i) procurement; (ii) financial management and audit; (iii) project 
management; (iv) environmental and social safeguards, (v) disaster risk management and climate 
resilience; and (vi) gender empowerment and social inclusion. In addition to a full-time financial 
management consultant, ADB staff will provide capacity support to project implementation unit 
staff on ADB’s financial management requirements and disbursement guidelines  to ensure 
robustness  and  transparency.  A  project  liaison  office  in  Coxsbazar  will  be  established  to 
coordinate and facilitate subproject development, implementation, and monitoring. The TA will 
support the government’s RRRC and the liaison office on logistics including vehicles, office 
equipment, and capacity building. 
 
8.  Output  2:  Planning,  design,  and  implementation  of  the  proposed  subprojects 
supported. The TA will mobilize adequate national consultants to help implementing agencies 
overcome their capacity constraints and low readiness on subproject selection, technical and 
safeguard due diligence, design, procurement, and contract management. TA consultants for 
each sector will support (i) the preparation of development project proforma, technical assistance 
project proforma including technical and economic due diligence and bid documents; and (ii) bid 
evaluation. Similarly, project implementation units will be reinforced with consultants to help with 
construction supervision, safeguard application, sound application of communication strategy, 
gender equity and social inclusion action plan, and reporting. In addition, pilot testing of project 
approach will be supported. 
 
9.  Output 3: Effective monitoring and evaluation established. A well-functioning project 
monitoring and management information system will be established in four project implementation

3 
units and their district counterparts to monitor progress on procurement, quality of equipment and 
civil works, contract management, implementation, fund flows, accounting, audit, and reporting 
functions.  TA  consultants  will  operationalize  the  system  through  a  project  liaison  office  in 
Coxsbazar. Quarterly coordination meetings among ADB, RRRC, the local deputy commissioner, 
UN agencies, and development partners will be held at the liaison office.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
10.  The TA is estimated to cost $3,100,000, of which $3,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6) of ADB. The key expenditure items are 
listed in Appendix 1. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart 
staff, office accommodation, office supplies, secretarial assistance, local transportation, and other 
in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
11.  ADB will administer the TA. The Bangladesh Resident Mission will select, supervise, and 
evaluate consultants; and procure goods under the TA. The overall consultants’ inputs will be 
finalized in consultation with the implementing agencies. The TA will be implemented over 36 
months from July 2018 to June 2021. 
 
12.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 1. 
 
Table 1: Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  July 2018–June 2021 
Executing agency  ADB 
Implementing agency  ADB

technical assistance. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
13.  Consulting services. Consultant recruitment will follow the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or 
staff instructions. TA implementation will be carried out through national individual consultants 
(279 person-months). Consulting firms, if required, will be recruited through open competitive 
bidding procedures, local advertisement, and/or limited competitive bidding using quality- and 
cost-based selection method, simplified technical proposal, or biodata technical proposal. Other 
selection methods such as consultants’ qualification-based selection is also envisaged. Individual 
consultants  will  be  recruited  following  individual  selection  method,  international  or  local 
advertisement, based on project requirements. Consultants engaged in ADB-financed projects 
for similar services may either be extended or selected through single-source selection, subject 
to the satisfactory performance of the consultant. This arrangement will provide an efficient way 
to recruit consultants under the circumstances. Some social and gender studies and support may 
be provided using local nongovernment organizations. The option to have a direct contract or 
memorandum of understanding with nongovernment organizations and/or UN agencies already 
engaged in the project area will also be explored, as appropriate.  
 
14.  Consulting  services  will  commence  in  July  2018,  to  be  rendered  full  time  and/or 
intermittently until June 2021.7 
 
15.  The  consultants  will  support  the  preparation  of  engineering  designs  for  the  typical 
subproject such as (i) mini piped water supply systems with production tube wells (chlorinated, 
solar-powered, groundwater-based); (ii) integrated waste management (both fecal and solid 
waste) and resource recovery facilities (with collection system) at the outskirts of the camps; (iii) 
construction of surface water treatment plants for supporting water supply at Coxsbazar District 
and surrounding areas, with a capacity of 350 m3 per hour water intake from Bankhali river; (iv) 
surface water reservoirs and associated facility to expand the existing surface water treatment 
system from 300 m3 to 450 m3 per day; (v) construction of 33/11 kilovolt (10 megavolt-ampere) 
substation at Palongkhali (Ukhiya); and (vi) installation of mini-grid solar system for household 
electricity use within the camp (150 households per cluster). The consultants will also support in 
finalizing design scheme tender packages for all other subprojects. 
 
16.  Pilot testing. The TA will support the pilot testing of (i) a thunder and lightning alert system 
at the campsite by establishing a weather station and a mobile application, and (ii) a biomass 
waste-to-energy production. The scope, sites, permits and clearances, and treatment of assets 
of the pilot test will be finalized in consultation with RRRC and implementing agencies during the 
inception mission. The activities will not result in any potential adverse environmental and/or 
social impact. The procurement plan will be prepared and updated once the scope of the pilot test 
is finalized. 
 
E.  Governance 
 
17.  Governance with respect to procurement, recruitment, and financial management will be 
as stated in the report and recommendation of the President. 
                                                
7 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).
